standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:        $|x| < |-7|$         **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: The inequality $|x| < |-7|$ means that $x$ is  closer to $0$ than $-7$ is.     [[☃ image 1]]  All numbers between $-7$ and $7$ are closer to $0$ than $-7$ is.

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line starts at negative 7 and ends at 7.

hints.content: $-2$ and $6$ are closer to $0$ than $-7$ is.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line starts at negative 7 and ends at 7. A closed point labeled negative 8 is plotted 2 tick marks to the right of negative 10. A closed point labeled negative 2 is plotted 2 tick marks to the left of 0. A closed point labeled 6 is plotted 6 tick marks to the right of 0.

hints.content: We can also plug in each number for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}|-2| &< |-7|\\ \green{2}&\green<\green{7}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|6| &< |-7|\\ \green{6}&\green<\green{7}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|-8| &< |-7|\\ \red{8}&\red<\red{7}\end{align}$   $$
$-2$ and $6$ are possible values for $x$.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:       $|x| > |-10|$        **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: The inequality $|x| > |-10|$ means that $x$ is farther away from $0$ than $-10$ is.   [[☃ image 1]]  All numbers less than $-10$ and all numbers greater than $10$ are farther away from $0$ than $-10$ is.

images.alt: A number line from negative 20 to 20 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 5. A line going to the left starts at negative 10 and continues left. A line going to the right starts at 10 and continues right.

hints.content: $-17$ and $11$ are farther from $0$ than $-10$ is.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 20 to 20 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 5. A line going to the left starts at negative 10 and continues left. A line going to the right starts at 10 and continues right. A closed point labeled negative 17 is plotted between negative 20 and the first tick mark to the right of negative 20. A closed point labeled negative 1 is plotted between 0 and the first tick mark to the left of 0. A closed point labeled 11 is plotted between 10 and the first tick mark to the right of 10.

hints.content: We can also plug in each number for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}|-17| &> |-10|\\ \green{17}&\green>\green{10}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|-1| &> |-10|\\ \red{1}&\red>\red{10}\end{align}$    $$    $\,\,\,\,\begin{align}|11| &> |-10|\\ \green{11}&\green>\green{10}\end{align}$
$-17$ and $11$ are possible values for $x$.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:       $|x| > |5|$        **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: The inequality $|x| > |5|$ means that $x$ is farther away from $0$ than $5$ is.    [[☃ image 1]]  All numbers less than $-5$ and all numbers greater than $5$ are farther away from $0$ than $5$ is.

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line going to the left starts at negative 5 and continues left. A line going to the right starts at 5 and continues right.

hints.content: $9$ is farther from $0$ than $5$ is.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line going to the left starts at negative 5 and continues left. A line going to the right starts at 5 and continues right. A closed point labeled negative 4 is plotted 1 tick mark to the right of negative 5. A closed point labeled 3 is plotted 3 tick marks to the right of 0. A closed point labeled 9 is plotted 1 tick mark to the left of 10.

hints.content: We can also plug in each number for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}|9| &> |5|\\ \green{9}&\green>\green{5}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|3| &> |5|\\ \red{3}&\red>\red{5}\end{align}$    $$    $\begin{align}|-4| &> |5|\\ \red{4}&\red>\red{5}\end{align}$    $$
$9$ is a possible value for $x$.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:         $|x| < |14|$        **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: The inequality $|x| < |14|$ means that $x$ is  closer to $0$ than $14$ is.    [[☃ image 1]]  All numbers between $-14$ and $14$ are closer to $0$ than $14$ is.

images.alt: A number line from negative 20 to 20 with 7 unequally spaced tick marks . The tick marks are labeled left to right: negative 20, negative 14, negative 10, 0, 10, 14, and 20. A line starts at negative 14 and ends at 14.

hints.content: $-12$, $0$, and $5$ are closer to $0$ than $14$ is.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 20 to 20 with 7 unequally spaced tick marks . The tick marks are labeled left to right: negative 20, negative 14, negative 10, 0, 10, 14, and 20. A line starts at negative 14 and ends at 14. A closed point labeled negative 12 is plotted between negative 14 and negative 10. A closed point labeled 0 is plotted at 0. A closed point labeled 5 is plotted between 0 and 10.

hints.content: We can also plug in each number for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}|-12| &< |14|\\ \green{12}&\green<\green{14}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|0| &< |14|\\ \green{0}&\green<\green{14}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|5| &< |14|\\ \green{5}&\green<\green{14}\end{align}$   $$
$-12$, $0$, and $5$ are possible values for $x$.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:        $|x |< 9$        **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: The inequality $|x| < 9$ means that $x$ is closer to $0$ than $9$ is.    [[☃ image 1]]  All numbers between $-9$ and $9$ are closer to $0$ than $9$ is.

images.alt: A number line from negative 15 to 15 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line starts 1 tick mark to the right of negative 10 and ends 1 tick mark to the left of 10.

hints.content: $7$'s distance from $0$ is less than $9$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 15 to 15 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line starts 1 tick mark to the right of negative 10 and ends 1 tick mark to the left of 10. A closed point labeled negative 10 is plotted at negative 10. A closed point labeled 7 is plotted 2 tick marks to the right of 5.  A closed point labeled 13 is plotted 2 tick marks to the left of 15.

hints.content: We can also plug in each number for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}|7| &< 9\\ \green{7}&\green<\green{9}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|-10| &< 9\\ \red{10}&\red<\red{9}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|13| &< 9\\ \red{13}&\red<\red{9}\end{align}$   $$
$7$ is a possible value for $x$.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:        $|x |> -16$        **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: Absolute value is always positive.  So, $|x|$ is a positive number.    $-16$ is a negative number.
A positive number is always greater than a negative number.  So, we can plug any number for $x$ and make the inequality true.

We can also plug in the given numbers for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}|19| &>-16\\ \green{19}&\green>\green{-16}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|3| &>-16\\ \green{3}&\green>\green{-16}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}|-15| &>-16\\ \green{15}&\green>\green{-16}\end{align}$   $$
$-15$, $3$, and $19$ are possible values for $x$.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:        $x < |-3|$        **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: $|-3|=3$  So, $x< |-3|$ is the same as $x<3$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line going to the left starts 3 tick marks to the right of 0 and continues left.

hints.content: $-8$ and $0$ are less than $3$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line going to the left starts 3 tick marks to the right of 0 and continues left. A point labeled negative 8 is plotted 2 tick marks to the right of negative 10. A point labeled  0 is plotted at 0. A point labeled 4 is plotted 1 tick mark to the left of 5.

hints.content: We can also plug in each number for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}-8&< |-3|\\ \green{-8}&\green<\green{3}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}0&< |-3|\\ \green{0}&\green<\green{3}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}4&< |-3|\\ \red{4}&\red<\red{3}\end{align}$   $$
$-8$ and $0$ are possible values for $x$.

question.content: We want the following inequality to be true:        $x >|2|$        **Which of the following are possible values for $x$?**

hints.content: $|2|=2$  So, $x> |2|$ is the same as $x>2$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line going to the right starts 2 tick marks to the left of 0 and continues right.

hints.content: $5$ is greater than $2$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from negative 10 to 10 with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1. A line going to the right starts 2 tick marks to the left of 0 and continues right. A closed point labeled negative 9 is plotted 1 tick mark to the right of negative 10. A closed point labeled 1 is plotted 1 tick mark to the right of 0. A closed point labeled 5 is plotted at 5.

hints.content: We can also plug in each number for $x$ to see if the inequality is $\green{\text{true}}$:   $\begin{align}5&> |2|\\ \green{5}&\green>\green{2}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}1&> |2|\\ \red{1}&\red>\red{2}\end{align}$   $$  $\begin{align}-9&> |2|\\ \red{-9}&\red>\red{2}\end{align}$   $$
$5$ is a possible value for $x$.

question.content: **Use the following number line to determine if the expressions are true or false.**

images.alt: A number line with evenly spaced tick marks. The tick mark in the middle is labeled 0. A closed point labeled a is plotted 3 tick marks to the left of 0. A closed point labeled b is plotted 1 tick mark to the right of 0.

hints.content: First, let's plot $|\blue{a}|$ and $|\pink{b}|$.  Absolute value is a number's distance from $0$.      [[☃ image 1]]  Remember, distance is always zero or positive.

images.alt: A number line with evenly spaced tick marks. The tick mark in the middle is labeled 0. A closed point labeled a is plotted 3 tick marks to the left of 0. A closed point labeled b above the number line and labeled absolute value of b under the number line is plotted 1 tick mark to the right of 0. A closed point labeled absolute value of a is plotted 3 tick marks to the right of 0.

hints.content: On a number line, numbers to the right are greater than numbers to the left.
[[☃ categorizer 1]]

question.content: **Use the following number line to determine if the expressions are true or false.**

images.alt: A number line with evenly spaced tick marks. The tick mark in the middle is labeled 0. A closed point labeled a is plotted 1 tick mark to the left of 0. A closed point labeled b is plotted between the third and fourth tick marks to the right of 0.

hints.content: First, let's plot $|\blue{a}|$ and $|\pink{b}|$.  Absolute value is a number's distance from $0$.     [[☃ image 1]]  Remember, distance is always zero or positive.

images.alt: A number line with evenly spaced tick marks. The tick mark in the middle is labeled 0. A closed point labeled a is plotted 1 tick mark to the left of 0. A closed point labeled absolute value of a is plotted 1 tick mark to the right of 0. A closed point labeled b above the number line and labeled absolute value of b under the number line is plotted between the third and fourth tick marks to the right of 0.

hints.content: On a number line, numbers to the left are less than numbers to the right.
[[☃ categorizer 1]]

hints.content: First, let's plot $|\blue{a}|$ and $|\pink{b}|$.  Absolute value is a number's distance from $0$.     [[☃ image 1]]  Remember, distance is always zero or positive.
